token.field.allowed_domains_helper: Leave empty to allow all domains. Subdomains are automatically included.
token.notification.created_body: This token will not be shown again. Copy it now and store it securely.

docs.intro.title: One GitHub token. Unlimited team access.
docs.intro.description: Configure GitHub credentials once here. Distribute simple Packgrid tokens to your team and CI/CD.
docs.intro.warning.title: Important Notice
docs.intro.warning.description: Please read before using Packgrid in production.
docs.intro.warning.item1: Use at your own risk — Packgrid is provided as-is, without warranty of any kind
docs.intro.warning.item2: Security is your responsibility — Ensure your server is properly secured with HTTPS and firewall rules
docs.intro.warning.item3: Backup your data — Regularly backup your database and configuration
docs.intro.warning.item4: Token management — Treat Packgrid tokens like passwords. Rotate them regularly and revoke unused ones
docs.intro.warning.item5: Not a replacement for proper access control — Packgrid simplifies distribution, but you should still follow security best practices
docs.intro.section.what_is_desc: A simple solution for a common problem
docs.intro.what_is.p1: Packgrid is a lightweight, self-hosted private Composer repository server designed for developers and teams who need to manage and distribute private PHP packages without relying on third-party services like Private Packagist.
docs.intro.what_is.p2: Built with Laravel and Filament, Packgrid follows the philosophy of keeping things simple. It does one thing well: serving your private packages to Composer with proper authentication.
docs.intro.problem.intro: When working with private GitHub repositories as Composer packages, you typically have two options:
docs.intro.problem.option1: Use GitHub directly — Works, but requires SSH keys or OAuth tokens on every machine and CI/CD pipeline that needs access
docs.intro.problem.option2: Pay for Private Packagist — Great service, but can be expensive for small teams or personal projects
docs.intro.problem.packgrid1: Self-host your own Composer server — Full control over your packages with simple token-based authentication
docs.intro.problem.packgrid2: One GitHub token, multiple users — Configure GitHub access once in Packgrid, then distribute simple Packgrid tokens to your team
docs.intro.problem.packgrid3: Works with any Composer project — Standard Composer repository, no special plugins required
docs.intro.compare.intro: There are several solutions for hosting private Composer packages. Here's how Packgrid compares:
docs.intro.compare.summary: Packgrid's niche: If you need a simple, free, self-hosted solution for distributing private GitHub packages to your team without the complexity of Satis or the cost of Private Packagist, Packgrid is a good fit. For enterprise features like security scanning, license review, or complex team permissions, consider Private Packagist or Repman.
docs.intro.features.item1: GitHub Integration — Connect your GitHub repositories (public and private) using personal access tokens
docs.intro.features.item2: Token Authentication — Create and manage access tokens for your team members or CI/CD pipelines
docs.intro.features.item3: Automatic Sync — Packages are synced from GitHub and served through Composer's standard HTTP protocol
docs.intro.features.item4: Simple Admin Panel — Manage repositories, credentials, and tokens through a clean Filament interface
docs.intro.future.intro: Packgrid is intentionally kept simple, but there are some features that might be added in the future:
docs.intro.future.item1: GitLab Support — Connect to self-hosted or gitlab.com repositories
docs.intro.future.item2: Bitbucket Support — Integrate with Bitbucket Cloud and Server
docs.intro.future.item3: Gitea/Forgejo Support — Support for self-hosted Git platforms
docs.intro.future.item4: Webhooks — Automatic sync when you push to your repositories
docs.intro.future.item5: Security Scanning — Alert on known vulnerabilities in your packages
docs.intro.future.outro: These features will only be added if they don't compromise the simplicity of the project.
docs.intro.getting_started.intro: Head over to the Setup Guide tab for step-by-step instructions on configuring Composer to use your Packgrid server. If you run into any issues, check the Troubleshooting tab for common error solutions.
docs.intro.getting_started.item1: Add a GitHub credential for private repository access
docs.intro.getting_started.item3: Create access tokens for your team
docs.how.title: Understanding the Magic Behind Packgrid
docs.how.description: See exactly how your private packages travel from GitHub to your project, and how authentication keeps everything secure.
docs.how.section.phase1_desc: How Packgrid learns about your packages
docs.how.section.phase2_desc: What happens when you run composer require
docs.how.section.auth_flow_desc: How security is maintained at each step
docs.how.alert.no_files_desc: During sync, Packgrid only stores metadata (package names, versions, dependencies). The actual source code files are never downloaded or stored on Packgrid.
docs.how.alert.security_desc: If a developer's machine is compromised, the attacker only gets a Packgrid token which can be easily revoked. Your GitHub token (which may have broader access) remains safe on the Packgrid server.
docs.how.alert.streaming_desc: Packgrid does not store package files on disk. When you download a package, it streams directly from GitHub through Packgrid to your project. This means no additional storage is needed, but it also means each download requires a GitHub API call.
docs.how.phase1.intro: Before your project can install packages, Packgrid needs to know about them. This happens during the sync phase, triggered manually or by schedule.
docs.how.phase1.step1_desc: Packgrid uses your stored GitHub credential to list all tags and branches.
docs.how.phase1.step2_desc: For each tag/branch, Packgrid fetches the composer.json to understand dependencies and package name.
docs.how.phase1.step3_desc: Packgrid builds and stores a Composer-compatible package index (packages.json) with download URLs pointing back to Packgrid.
docs.how.phase2.intro: When you run composer require vendor/package in your project, here's the complete flow:
docs.how.phase2.step1_desc: Composer requests the package list from Packgrid, authenticating with your Packgrid token from auth.json.
docs.how.phase2.step2_desc: Packgrid returns the package index with all available versions and their download URLs.
docs.how.phase2.step3_desc: Composer requests the actual package zip file from the URL in the metadata.
docs.how.phase2.step4_desc: Packgrid uses its stored GitHub credential to download the zipball from GitHub's API.
docs.how.phase2.step5_desc: The zip file streams through Packgrid directly to your project. Packgrid acts as a secure proxy.
docs.how.auth.intro: The key security benefit of Packgrid is credential isolation. Your GitHub token never leaves the Packgrid server.
docs.how.auth.point1: Your Project only knows about the Packgrid token. It has no access to GitHub credentials.
docs.how.auth.point2: Packgrid validates Packgrid tokens and uses GitHub credentials internally for API calls.
docs.how.auth.point3: GitHub only sees requests from Packgrid, never from individual developers or CI/CD systems.
docs.how.data.intro: A common question is whether those thousands of files from your private repository actually pass through Packgrid. Yes, they do — but as a stream.
docs.how.data.point1: Metadata requests — Package index and version info (small JSON files, ~1-100KB)
docs.how.data.point2: Package downloads — Zip files containing all repository files (streamed, not stored)
docs.how.summary.point1: Sync Phase: Packgrid reads repository metadata from GitHub and builds a Composer-compatible index
docs.how.summary.point2: Install Phase: Composer gets metadata from Packgrid, then downloads packages through Packgrid
docs.how.summary.point3: Authentication: Projects use Packgrid tokens; Packgrid uses GitHub tokens internally
docs.how.summary.point4: Data Flow: Actual package files stream through Packgrid (not stored) on every download
docs.how.summary.point5: Security: GitHub credentials never leave Packgrid; only revocable Packgrid tokens are distributed

docs.setup.description: Follow these simple steps to configure Packgrid and start installing your private packages with Composer.
docs.setup.tip1: Private repos require a GitHub credential in Packgrid
docs.setup.tip2: Create Packgrid tokens for Composer authentication
docs.setup.tip3: Run a sync after adding repositories
docs.setup.tip4: Place auth.json next to composer.json or globally

docs.setup.step1.instruction2: Name the token Packgrid and select the repo scope
docs.setup.step1.instruction3: Copy the token and create a credential in Packgrid
docs.setup.step1.instruction4: Link your private repositories to this credential when adding them
docs.setup.step2.heading: Server URL
docs.setup.step3.heading: composer.json
docs.setup.step3.description: Add Packgrid as a Composer repository
docs.setup.step4.heading: auth.json
docs.setup.step4.instruction: Create a token in Tokens and add it to your auth.json:
docs.setup.step4_alt.heading: Authentication (Optional)
docs.setup.step4_alt.description: Currently public. Create a token to require authentication.
docs.setup.step5.heading: Install Package
docs.setup.step5.description: Require your private package via Composer

docs.troubleshooting.heading: The solution for your error is probably here.
docs.troubleshooting.ssl.title: SSL Certificate Error
docs.troubleshooting.ssl.description: curl error 60: SSL peer certificate was not OK
docs.troubleshooting.ssl.message: curl error 60 while downloading https://packgrid.test/packages.json: SSL peer certificate or SSH remote key was not OK
docs.troubleshooting.ssl.solution: For local development with self-signed certificates, add SSL options to your repository config in composer.json:
docs.troubleshooting.json.title: Invalid JSON in auth.json
docs.troubleshooting.json.message:
"auth.json" does not contain valid JSON
Parse error on line 1: Expected one of: 'STRING', 'NUMBER', 'NULL', 'TRUE', 'FALSE', '{', '['
docs.troubleshooting.json.solution: Ensure your auth.json contains valid JSON. Use a JSON validator to check for syntax errors like missing quotes, trailing commas, or incorrect brackets.
docs.troubleshooting.credentials.title: Invalid Credentials (HTTP 401)
docs.troubleshooting.credentials.solutio: Check that the token in your auth.json is correct
Verify the token is enabled in Packgrid and has not expired
Ensure the host in auth.json matches your Packgrid server exactly
docs.troubleshooting.notfound.title: Package Not Found
docs.troubleshooting.notfound.descriptio: Could not find a matching version of package
docs.troubleshooting.notfound.message: Could not find a matching version of package vendor/package. Check the package spelling, your version constraint and that the package is available in a stability which matches your minimum-stability (stable).
docs.troubleshooting.notfound.solution1: The package name must match the "name" field in the repository's composer.json, not the GitHub repository name
docs.troubleshooting.notfound.solution2: Ensure the repository has been synced in Packgrid (check the Repositories page for sync status)
docs.troubleshooting.notfound.solution3: Laravel projects have "name": "laravel/laravel" by default - this needs to be changed to use them as packages
docs.troubleshooting.stability.title: Minimum Stability Mismatch
docs.troubleshooting.stability.message: Could not find a version of package vendor/package matching your minimum-stability (stable). Require it with an explicit version constraint allowing its desired stability.
docs.troubleshooting.stability.solution1: If the package only has dev versions (no stable tags), you can either:
docs.troubleshooting.stability.solution3: Or add minimum-stability to your composer.json:
docs.troubleshooting.branch.title: Branch Name Mismatch
docs.troubleshooting.branch.message: Root composer.json requires vendor/package dev-master, found vendor/package[dev-main] but it does not match the constraint. Perhaps dev-master was renamed to dev-main?
docs.troubleshooting.branch.solution: Many repositories have renamed their default branch from master to main. Use the correct branch name:
docs.troubleshooting.dependency.title: Dependency Resolution Failed
docs.troubleshooting.dependency.message:
Your requirements could not be resolved to an installable set of packages.

Problem 1
  - vendor/package dev-main requires some/dependency ^4.0
  - some/dependency is fixed to 3.0.0 (lock file version)

Use the option --with-all-dependencies (-W) to allow upgrades.
docs.troubleshooting.dependency.solution: When installing a package requires updating other locked dependencies, use the -W flag to allow Composer to update all related packages:
docs.npm.intro.title: Private npm packages from GitHub.
docs.npm.intro.description: Serve your private GitHub repositories as npm packages with simple Bearer token authentication.
docs.npm.intro.warning.title: Important Notice
docs.npm.intro.warning.description: Please read before using Packgrid for npm packages.
docs.npm.intro.warning.item1: Scoped packages only — npm packages must be scoped (e.g., @myorg/package)
docs.npm.intro.warning.item2: Bearer token authentication — npm uses Bearer tokens in .npmrc, not http-basic like Composer
docs.npm.intro.warning.item3: Tarball proxying — Packgrid proxies .tgz downloads from GitHub releases or generates them from zipballs
docs.npm.intro.warning.item4: Security is your responsibility — Ensure your server is properly secured with HTTPS
docs.npm.intro.what_is.p1: Packgrid can serve your private GitHub repositories as an npm registry, allowing you to install them with npm, yarn, or pnpm just like any public package.
docs.npm.intro.what_is.p2: The npm protocol uses a different format than Composer. Instead of packages.json and zip files, npm uses package metadata endpoints and .tgz tarballs.
docs.npm.intro.differences.item1: Scoped packages — npm packages must use scopes like @myorg/package-name
docs.npm.intro.differences.item2: Bearer authentication — npm uses //registry:_authToken=TOKEN in .npmrc instead of auth.json
docs.npm.intro.differences.item3: Tarball format — npm downloads .tgz files instead of zip archives
docs.npm.intro.differences.item4: Metadata format — npm uses a different JSON structure for package metadata
docs.npm.intro.features.item1: Scoped package installation — Install packages like npm install @myorg/package
docs.npm.intro.features.item2: Version resolution — Supports semantic versioning and version ranges
docs.npm.intro.features.item3: Bearer token auth — Standard npm authentication via .npmrc
docs.npm.intro.features.item4: Works with npm, yarn, pnpm — Compatible with all major package managers
docs.npm.intro.section.compare_desc: Comparison with npm private registry alternatives
docs.npm.intro.compare.intro: There are several solutions for hosting private npm packages. Here's how Packgrid compares:
docs.npm.intro.compare.summary: Packgrid's advantage: If you already use Packgrid for Composer packages, adding npm support requires zero additional setup. You get a unified registry for both PHP and JavaScript packages with the same token management and GitHub integration.
docs.npm.intro.getting_started.intro: Head over to the Setup Guide tab for step-by-step instructions on configuring npm to use your Packgrid server. If you run into any issues, check the Troubleshooting tab for common error solutions.
docs.npm.intro.getting_started.item1: Add a GitHub credential for private repository access
docs.npm.intro.getting_started.item2: Register your repositories with npm format
docs.npm.how.title: How npm Packages Flow Through Packgrid
docs.npm.how.description: Understand how your private packages travel from GitHub to your project using the npm protocol.
docs.npm.how.section.phase1_desc: How Packgrid learns about your npm packages
docs.npm.how.phase1.intro: Before your project can install packages, Packgrid needs to sync the repository. During sync, Packgrid reads the package.json from each tag/branch.
docs.npm.how.phase1.step1_desc: Packgrid uses your stored GitHub credential to list all tags and branches.
docs.npm.how.phase1.step2_desc: For each tag/branch, Packgrid fetches the package.json to understand the package name and dependencies.
docs.npm.how.phase1.step3_desc: Packgrid builds npm-compatible package metadata with tarball URLs pointing back to Packgrid.
docs.npm.how.alert.scoped_desc: npm packages from Packgrid must be scoped (e.g., @myorg/package). The scope is determined by the "name" field in package.json.
docs.npm.how.section.phase2_desc: What happens when you run npm install
docs.npm.how.phase2.intro: When you run npm install @myorg/package in your project:
docs.npm.how.phase2.step1_desc: npm requests package info from Packgrid, authenticating with your Bearer token from .npmrc.
docs.npm.how.phase2.step2_desc: Packgrid returns npm-format metadata with version info and tarball URLs.
docs.npm.how.phase2.step3_desc: npm requests the .tgz tarball from the URL in the metadata.
docs.npm.how.phase2.step4_desc: Packgrid downloads the zipball from GitHub and converts it to a tarball.
docs.npm.how.phase2.step5_desc: The .tgz file streams through Packgrid directly to your project.
docs.npm.how.auth.intro: npm uses Bearer token authentication configured in .npmrc:
docs.npm.how.auth.point1: Your Project sends the Bearer token from .npmrc with each request
docs.npm.how.auth.point2: Packgrid validates the token and uses GitHub credentials internally
docs.npm.how.auth.point3: GitHub only sees requests from Packgrid with its stored credentials
docs.npm.how.alert.security_desc: Your GitHub token stays on the Packgrid server. Team members only need revocable Packgrid tokens in their .npmrc files.
docs.npm.how.summary.point1: Sync Phase: Packgrid reads package.json from GitHub and builds npm metadata
docs.npm.how.summary.point2: Install Phase: npm gets metadata from /@scope/package, then downloads .tgz tarballs
docs.npm.how.summary.point3: Authentication: Bearer token in .npmrc authenticates with Packgrid
docs.npm.how.summary.point4: Data Flow: Tarballs stream through Packgrid (converted from GitHub zipballs)
docs.npm.how.summary.point5: Security: GitHub credentials stay on Packgrid; only revocable tokens are distributed
docs.npm.setup.title: Configure npm for Private Packages
docs.npm.setup.description: Follow these steps to configure your project to install private npm packages from Packgrid.
docs.npm.setup.step1.title: Step 1: Create a GitHub Credential
docs.npm.setup.step1.intro: If your npm packages are in private GitHub repositories, you need to add a GitHub credential in Packgrid:
docs.npm.setup.step1.item3: Enter your GitHub Personal Access Token with repo scope
docs.npm.setup.step2.title: Step 2: Register Your Repository
docs.npm.setup.step2.intro: Register your GitHub repository as an npm package:
docs.npm.setup.step2.alert.title: package.json Required
docs.npm.setup.step2.alert.description: Your repository must have a package.json with a scoped name like "@myorg/package-name".
docs.npm.setup.step3.title: Step 3: Create a Packgrid Token
docs.npm.setup.step3.intro: Create an access token to authenticate npm requests:
docs.npm.setup.step3.item3: Copy the generated token (you'll need it for .npmrc)
docs.npm.setup.step4.title: Step 4: Configure .npmrc
docs.npm.setup.step4.intro: Create or edit .npmrc in your project root (or globally in your home directory):
docs.npm.setup.step4.alert.title: Replace Values
docs.npm.setup.step4.alert.description: Replace @myorg with your actual scope and YOUR_PACKGRID_TOKEN with the token from Step 3.
docs.npm.setup.step5.title: Step 5: Install Your Package
docs.npm.setup.step5.intro: Now you can install your private package:
docs.npm.setup.tip2: The scope in .npmrc must match your package scope
docs.npm.setup.tip3: Run sync after adding new repositories
docs.npm.setup.tip4: Works with npm, yarn, and pnpm
docs.npm.troubleshooting.heading: npm Error Solutions
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e401.title: E401 Unauthorized
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e401.message:
npm ERR! code E401
npm ERR! 401 Unauthorized - GET https://packgrid.test/npm/@myorg/package
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e401.solution_i: This error occurs when npm cannot authenticate with Packgrid. Check your .npmrc configuration:
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e401.solution1: Verify the token in .npmrc is correct and active
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e401.solution2: Ensure the registry URL matches your Packgrid server
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e401.solution3: Check that the _authToken line uses the correct host
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e404.title: E404 Package Not Found
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e404.descriptio: Package does not exist or not synced
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e404.message:
npm ERR! code E404
npm ERR! 404 Not Found - GET https://packgrid.test/npm/@myorg/package
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e404.solution1: Verify the package name matches the "name" field in package.json
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e404.solution2: Ensure the repository is registered in Packgrid
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e404.solution3: Run a Sync on the repository in Packgrid
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e404.solution4: Check that the scope in your install command matches the package scope
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e400.title: E400 Bad Request
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e400.descriptio: URL encoding issue with scoped packages
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e400.message:
npm ERR! code E400
npm ERR! 400 Bad Request - GET https://packgrid.test/npm/%40myorg%2Fpackage
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e400.solution_i: This usually indicates a URL encoding issue with scoped package names. Packgrid should handle URL-encoded scopes (like %40 for @).
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e400.solution1: Verify Packgrid is running the latest version
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e400.solution2: Check that the registry URL in .npmrc ends with a trailing slash
docs.npm.troubleshooting.e400.solution3: Try clearing npm cache: npm cache clean --force
docs.npm.troubleshooting.ssl.title: SSL Certificate Error
docs.npm.troubleshooting.ssl.message:
npm ERR! code UNABLE_TO_GET_ISSUER_CERT_LOCALLY
npm ERR! unable to get local issuer certificate
docs.npm.troubleshooting.ssl.solution_in: For local development with self-signed certificates, you can configure npm to skip SSL verification:
docs.npm.troubleshooting.ssl.warning: Warning: Only use this for local development. In production, use valid SSL certificates.
docs.npm.troubleshooting.scope.title: Registry Scope Mismatch
docs.npm.troubleshooting.scope.message:
npm ERR! code E404
npm ERR! 404 Not Found - GET https://registry.npmjs.org/@myorg/package
docs.npm.troubleshooting.scope.solution_: npm is trying to fetch from the public registry instead of Packgrid. Check your .npmrc scope configuration:
docs.npm.troubleshooting.scope.solution1: The scope line must match your package scope exactly (e.g., @myorg)
docs.npm.troubleshooting.scope.solution2: The .npmrc file must be in your project root or home directory
docs.npm.troubleshooting.scope.solution3: Try specifying the registry explicitly: npm install @myorg/package --registry=https://packgrid.test/npm/
docs.npm.troubleshooting.tarball.title: Tarball Download Failed
docs.npm.troubleshooting.tarball.message:
npm ERR! code EINTEGRITY
npm ERR! sha512 integrity checksum failed
docs.npm.troubleshooting.tarball.solutio: Delete node_modules and package-lock.json, then reinstall
Ensure Packgrid has access to the GitHub repository
Check that the repository has been synced recently
docs.npm.troubleshooting.packagejson.mes: Repository sync failed: package.json not found or invalid
docs.npm.troubleshooting.packagejson.sol: The repository must have a valid package.json with a scoped name:
The "name" field must be a scoped package name
The package.json must be valid JSON
Ensure the file is in the repository root
docs.docker.intro.title: Your Private Docker Registry
docs.docker.intro.description: Push and pull container images using your existing Packgrid tokens. OCI-compliant, simple authentication.
docs.docker.intro.info.title: Getting Started
docs.docker.intro.info.description: Before pushing images, make sure you have:
docs.docker.intro.info.item1: Create a Packgrid token — Go to Tokens and create an access token
docs.docker.intro.info.item2: Login with Docker — Use docker login with your token
docs.docker.intro.info.item3: Tag and push — Tag images with the registry URL and push
docs.docker.intro.section.what_is_desc: Private container registry built into Packgrid
docs.docker.intro.what_is.p1: Packgrid includes a fully functional private Docker registry that implements the OCI Distribution Specification. This means you can use standard Docker commands to push and pull container images.
docs.docker.intro.what_is.p2: Unlike public registries, your images are stored locally and accessed using the same Packgrid tokens you use for Composer and npm packages. No additional credentials or configuration needed.
docs.docker.intro.features.item1: Standard Docker commands — Use docker push and docker pull as usual
docs.docker.intro.features.item2: Token authentication — Reuse your existing Packgrid tokens
docs.docker.intro.features.item3: Blob deduplication — Shared image layers are stored once
docs.docker.intro.features.item4: Multi-architecture support — Store linux/amd64, linux/arm64, and more
docs.docker.intro.features.item5: Configurable storage — Use local disk, S3, or any Laravel filesystem
docs.docker.intro.section.getting_starte: Quick steps to get up and running
docs.docker.intro.getting_started.intro: Head over to the Setup Guide tab for step-by-step instructions.
docs.docker.intro.getting_started.item1: Create a Packgrid token (or reuse an existing one)
docs.docker.how.overview.p1: Packgrid implements the OCI Distribution Specification, which defines how Docker images are stored and transferred. When you push an image, several things happen:
docs.docker.how.overview.item1: Authentication — Docker sends your Packgrid token for verification
docs.docker.how.overview.item2: Layer upload — Each unique image layer (blob) is uploaded once
docs.docker.how.overview.item3: Manifest creation — The image manifest links layers together
docs.docker.how.overview.item4: Tag assignment — Tags (like v1.0 or latest) point to manifests
docs.docker.how.section.push_flow_desc: What happens when you push an image
docs.docker.how.push_flow.intro: When you run docker push, the following sequence occurs:
docs.docker.how.push_flow.step1: Docker checks which layers need to be uploaded (skips existing ones)
docs.docker.how.push_flow.step2: Each new layer is uploaded and stored with its SHA256 digest
docs.docker.how.push_flow.step3: The image manifest is uploaded, linking all layers together
docs.docker.how.push_flow.step4: The tag is created or updated to point to the new manifest
docs.docker.how.section.pull_flow_desc: What happens when you pull an image
docs.docker.how.pull_flow.step1: Docker fetches the manifest for the requested tag
docs.docker.how.pull_flow.step2: Docker checks which layers are missing locally
docs.docker.how.pull_flow.step3: Missing layers are downloaded from the registry
docs.docker.how.storage.p1: Packgrid stores image layers (blobs) using content-addressable storage. Each blob is identified by its SHA256 digest, meaning identical layers are only stored once, even if used by multiple repositories.
docs.docker.how.storage.p2: Storage is configurable via the PACKGRID_DOCKER_DISK environment variable. You can use local storage, S3, or any filesystem driver supported by Laravel.
docs.docker.setup.section.login_desc: Authenticate Docker with your Packgrid token
docs.docker.setup.login.intro: Use your Packgrid token as the password. The username can be anything (commonly token):
docs.docker.setup.login.token_note: Your credentials are stored in ~/.docker/config.json. You only need to login once per machine.
docs.docker.setup.section.push_desc: Tag and push your container image
docs.docker.setup.push.intro: Tag your local image with the registry URL and push:
docs.docker.setup.pull.intro: Pull images using the full registry path:
docs.docker.setup.section.compose_desc: Reference private images in compose files
docs.docker.setup.compose.intro: Reference your private images directly in docker-compose.yml:
docs.docker.setup.section.server_config_: Adjust PHP and web server limits to handle large Docker image layers
docs.docker.setup.server_config.intro: Docker images can be very large. You may need to increase upload limits on both PHP and your web server to handle Docker push operations.
docs.docker.setup.server_config.php_labe: Add the following to your php.ini or PHP-FPM pool configuration:
docs.docker.setup.server_config.nginx_la: For Nginx, add the following inside your server block:
docs.docker.setup.server_config.nginx_no: Setting client_max_body_size to 0 disables the upload size check entirely, which is recommended for a Docker registry since layer sizes vary widely.
docs.docker.setup.server_config.restart_: After changing these settings, restart PHP-FPM and reload your web server for the changes to take effect.
docs.docker.trouble.auth.intro: If you see authentication errors, check the following:
docs.docker.trouble.auth.check1: Verify your Packgrid token is valid and not expired
docs.docker.trouble.auth.check2: Ensure you logged in with the correct registry URL
docs.docker.trouble.auth.check3: Check that the token has not been disabled in Packgrid
docs.docker.trouble.push.intro: If your push fails, consider these common causes:
docs.docker.trouble.push.issue1: denied: requested access denied — Your token may lack push permissions or the repository is disabled
docs.docker.trouble.push.issue2: blob unknown — A layer reference is invalid. Try docker push again
docs.docker.trouble.push.issue3: manifest invalid — The image manifest is malformed. Rebuild the image
docs.docker.trouble.pull.intro: If you cannot pull an image:
docs.docker.trouble.pull.issue1: manifest unknown — The tag or digest does not exist. Check the repository for available tags
docs.docker.trouble.pull.issue2: blob unknown — A layer is missing. The image may be corrupted. Try pushing again
docs.docker.trouble.ssl.intro: For local development with self-signed certificates, you may need to configure Docker to trust your certificate or add your registry as an insecure registry in Docker's daemon.json.
docs.docker.trouble.ssl.warning: Only disable SSL verification for local development. Production registries should always use valid SSL certificates.

api.error.ip_denied: Access denied from this IP address.
token.field.allowed_repositories_helper: Leave empty to allow access to all repositories. Select specific repositories to restrict access.
token.error.repository_access_denied: Token is not authorized for this repository.
settings.title: Settings
settings.section.features_description: Enable or disable package repository features. At least one feature must be enabled.
settings.field.composer_enabled_helper: Enable Composer package registry for PHP packages.
settings.field.npm_enabled_helper: Enable NPM package registry for Node.js packages.
settings.field.docker_enabled_helper: Enable Docker container registry for OCI images.
settings.notification.at_least_one_requi: At least one feature must be enabled
token.section.network_restrictions_descr: Restrict token usage by IP address or domain.
token.section.package_restrictions_descr: Restrict access to specific Composer/NPM repositories.
token.section.docker_restrictions_descri: Restrict access to specific Docker repositories.
token.field.scope_repositories_helper: When enabled, this token can only access the selected repositories.
token.field.scope_docker_repositories_he: When enabled, this token can only access the selected Docker repositories.
token.field.allowed_docker_repositories_: Select the Docker repositories this token can access.
token.error.docker_repository_access_den: Token is not authorized for this Docker repository.
